prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: gamma Vel 400 GHz phase 0.0
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: He I and He II lines near 400 GHz. Orbital phase near phi=0.0 +/- 7 days.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: Explanation: the target, a binary star system, will be at orbital phase phi=0.0 on six dates during Cycle 2. These six dates are listed. Any one of them can be chosen. The period is 78.53 days, so that a scheduling margin of +/-7 days corresponds to less than +/- 0.1 in relative phase. This is acceptable for the science goal. It would be preferable---but not essential---if both science goal 1 (400 GHz band 8) and science goal 2 (232 GHz band 6) could be scheduled at nearly the same time. Both goals have the same timing requirement of orbital phase phi=0.0+/-0.1 and the same list of six possible time windows.

Both goals have the same timing requirement of orbital phase phi=0.0+/-0.1 and the same list of six possible time windows.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The technical challenge is to be sensitive to very broad emission lines (FWZI near 3000 km/s) on top of a continuum of ~ 0.49 Jy. The continuum source will be dominated by the unresolved central wind (~0.01 arcsec), but there may be interesting weaker emission from the outer wind on a scale of 1 to 2 arcsec. Thus a high S/N on the continuum is required, both for line detection and for possible weak extended continuum emission. Although the line emission of the unresolved central wind is expected to have a broad, smooth profile, it is possible that the wind-collision-region or wind clumps will produce line emission in much narrower (~10 to 100 km/s) features. The spectral setup has been optimized to include transitions of several different ions while allowing for broad lines; therefore, all of the spectral information is crucially important for the scientific goals. This is the justification of the high data rate. The target is a binary system with colliding winds. Observations are time-sensitive: it is essential to have an observation within +/-7 days of orbital phase 0.0 when the wind-collision region is best viewed. There are 6 possible time windows during Cycle 2. A separate Science Goal is concerned with the observation near orbital phase 0.5.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The technical challenge is to be sensitive to very broad emission lines (FWZI near 3000 km/s) on top of a continuum of ~ 0.36 Jy near 232 GHz. The continuum source will be dominated by the unresolved central wind (~0.01 arcsec), but there may be interesting weaker emission from the outer wind on a scale of 1 to 2 arcsec. Thus a high S/N on the continuum is required, both for line detection and for possible weak extended continuum emission. Although the line emission of the unresolved central wind is expected to have a broad, smooth profile, it is possible that the wind-collision-region or wind clumps will produce line emission in much narrower (~10 to 100 km/s) features. The spectral setup has been optimized to include transitions of several different ions while allowing for broad lines; therefore, all of the spectral information is crucially important for the scientific goals. This is the justification of the high data rate. The target is a binary system with colliding winds. Observations are time-sensitive: it is essential to have an observation within +/-7 days of orbital phase 0.5 to complement the phase 0.0 science goal. There are 7 possible time windows during Cycle 2. A separate Science Goal is concerned with the observation near orbital phase 0.0.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Ionized winds of hot, massive stars affect their evolution through mass loss and affect Galactic evolution through their input of mechanical energy and particle acceleration. These winds produce measurable free-free continuum flux at mm and submm wavelengths. Rydberg transitions of atoms and ions should be detectable in the winds of the nearest and brightest massive stars as broad emission lines, thus bringing a new kind of spectroscopy to the study of massive stars. Measurement of the intensities and profiles of these lines will yield improved constraints on inhomogeneities in the winds and will make it possible to measure the gas temperature in the outer wind. The proposed observations of the nearest Wolf-Rayet colliding-wind binary (gamma-2 Vel) will (1) demonstrate proof of concept for this novel spectroscopy, and (2) provide valuable new information about the winds of massive stars.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Earth and Space Sciences, Chalmers University of Technology
